awd_titl_txt: Altering the Course of Quantum Dynamics Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Herschel Rabitz of Princeton University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry.  The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms - A program co-funds the proposal. Rabitz seeks to understand the fundamental principles of using tailored laser fields to control phenomena at the molecular scale. Starting in the latter half of the 20th Century and accelerating to the present time, there is an increasing interest in using modern laser technology to directly manipulate the motion of atoms and molecules. Many experiments have demonstrated the feasibility of this concept.    Rabitz's research seeks a fundamental understanding for why such experiments are successful.   This understanding helps to provide a roadmap for performing new classes of laser experiments in the future. This roadmap includes the goal of achieving new laser-driven atomic and molecular scale transformations which are not achievable by any other means.  Furthermore, Rabitz's research findings are expected to be applicable to many domains of science where controlled manipulation is required to achieve the desired outcome, even without the aid of lasers, including in the chemical and biological sciences.
 
The control of quantum phenomena entails interceding in the normal evolution of atomic and molecular dynamical events generally through the introduction of external fields. Quite surprisingly, finding optimal fields for this purpose is proving to be far easier than anticipated, both in simulations and in the laboratory. Professor Herschel Rabitz undertakes fundamental research to understand the origins of this behavior. To address this matter at the most basic level, Rabitz explores the structure of the control landscape, which is the physical observable as a function of the control variables. The most fundamental circumstance will receive special attention, which the landscape associated with one quantum system controlling another. Rabitz will employ a family of theoretical and computational tools to analyze the landscape's topology, aiming to identify the basic rules for controlling quantum phenomena. Part of his effort includes the development of special techniques to reveal the mechanisms by which control is achieved. The outcome of Rabitz's research is expected to be a deeper understanding of controlled quantum phenomena along with specific guidance towards promising future experimental directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research presented the general foundations for when to expect quantum control to be successful in the laboratory. This finding rests on an assessment of the shape and structure of the so-called control landscape, which is the physical objective as a function of the control variables. The research showed under rather mild assumptions that quantum control is expected to be successful provided that adequate control resources are available. Building on this foundation, the research also developed a variety of efficient control algorithms to exploit and actually discover effective controls to meet quantum objectives. This latter research also included the introduction of a synergistic algorithm that draws on the best features of experimental activity combined with real time application of computational modeling to obtain a balanced approach to most effectively find quantum controls in the laboratory. The established theoretical foundations of quantum control in this research also revealed that generally many, if not an infinite number of, successful controls should exist in any particular application. This situation was shown to open up the prospect of not only reaching high fidelity for the control objective but also introducing ancillary objectives for optimization. A prime example of high importance is seeking robustness of the objective to naturally occurring uncertainty in the Hamiltonian and noise in the control field. It was shown that taking advantage of this opportunity is enabled by the control landscapes generically having flat domains at the top corresponding to multiple solutions for maximization of the original objective, and one can move in these domains with its corresponding control variables for optimization of the ancillary objectives. Finally, these general principles were shown to be relevant to the growing area of quantum information sciences where it is expected that the introduction of optimal controls should be able to enhance performance.
